# SYSTEM IDENTIFICATION ## System Name and Identifier *System Name* - Tactical Attitude Conversion Result (TACR) *Identifier* - XXX-XX-XX-XX-XX-XXXX-00 ## Responsible Organization The responsible organization for the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} is:
U. S. Department of Sobriety
Office of Special Details Division of Industry Improvement REDACTED Washington, DC 20XXX-7240
## System FIPS 199 Categorization This web site resides within the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} accreditation boundary and will be maintaining a FIPS 199 Category of Low unless a FIPS 199 categorization determines another category for the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system processes, stores or transmits the following information types, as described in NIST 800-60: C.2.6.2 Official Information Dissemination Information Type. Each information type has its own security categorization. The overall system security categorization is determined by taking the high water mark for each security objective (confidentiality, integrity, and availability) based on the information types being handled, as provided in NIST 800-60. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system is categorized as a low-impact system based on the overall security categorization of the information types being processed: {(confidentiality, Low (integrity, Low), (availability, Low per the guidelines contained in FIPS 199. ## Minimum Security Controls Because the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system is a low-impact application per FIPS 199, this system is subject to the low-impact baseline required by NIST Special Publication 800-53. Therefore, the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system uses the 800-53 low-impact baseline as its minimum-security control requirements. ## System Operational Status As defined in NIST SP 800-64, Security Considerations in the System Development Life Cycle, the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} Sites described herein are in the implementation/assessment phase of the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC). Controls

AC - Access Control

AC-1: Access Control Policy And Procedures

The organization: a. Develops, documents, and disseminates to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]: a.1. An access control policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and a.2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the access control policy and associated access controls; and b. Reviews and updates the current: b.1. Access control policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and b.2. Access control procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].
The Department develops, disseminates, and periodically reviews/updates: (i) a formal, documented, access control policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, and compliance, and formal, documented procedures to facilitate the implementation of the access control policy and associated access controls. **In-Place Controls:** Access control policy and procedures are documented in the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} SSP. Access to {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System operational information or system resources is limited to only authorized users, programs or processes. The Department enforces access control policies to protect the integrity of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system. This Department reviews and updates this policy as necessary and it has been being updated, as necessary, since April 2008. **Control Type:** Common Additional information is contained within the Department of Sobriety, Handbook for Information Assurance Security Policy.

AC-2: Account Management

The organization: a. Identifies and selects the following types of information system accounts to support organizational missions/business functions: [Assignment: organization-defined information system account types]; b. Assigns account managers for information system accounts; c. Establishes conditions for group and role membership; d. Specifies authorized users of the information system, group and role membership, and access authorizations (i.e., privileges) and other attributes (as required) for each account; e. Requires approvals by [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles] for requests to create information system accounts; f. Creates, enables, modifies, disables, and removes information system accounts in accordance with [Assignment: organization-defined procedures or conditions]; g. Monitors the use of information system accounts; h. Notifies account managers: h.1. When accounts are no longer required; h.2. When users are terminated or transferred; and h.3. When individual information system usage or need-to-know changes; i. Authorizes access to the information system based on: i.1. A valid access authorization; i.2. Intended system usage; and i.3. Other attributes as required by the organization or associated missions/business functions; j. Reviews accounts for compliance with account management requirements [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and k. Establishes a process for reissuing shared/group account credentials (if deployed) when individuals are removed from the group.
Information system accounts are managed, including establishing, activating, modifying, reviewing, disabling, and removing accounts. Data owners must review access authorizations and Information system accounts at least annually to determine whether they remain appropriate and also must periodically re-certify users, including for single sign-on computers. Access control lists are compiled and are reviewed. **In-Place Controls:** Access privileges are used to ensure that only authorized personnel access certain areas of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system. User access is controlled by the completion and submission of {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System System Rules of Behavior and New User Account Request forms by the user and management. These items are completed and submitted whenever a new user requires access or an existing user requires access changes. The system administrator, based on need-to-know, assigns the proper permissions. The employee’s manager approves the access rights before the initial account is created by signing off on the forms. Finally, the system administrator implements the access rights according to the New User Account Request form. The security staff and the support contractor to determine recertification requirements review accounts periodically. Accounts no longer in use are removed from the system by the system administrator. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System has implemented user account procedures to disable inactive user accounts after 90-days of inactivity. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} support staff monitors all user accounts to ensure this procedure is enforced. The Authentication Management section of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} SSP illustrates the exact procedures the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} support staff follows to ensure accounts are properly managed. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system does not have guest or anonymous accounts. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-3: Access Enforcement

The information system enforces approved authorizations for logical access to information and system resources in accordance with applicable access control policies.
The information system enforces assigned authorizations for controlling access to the system in accordance with applicable policy. **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System ensures that assigned authorizations for controlling access to the system is enforced in accordance with the user definitions noted in the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} SSP. The technical support staff ensures that access to security functions and protected information is restricted to authorized personnel. Access will be controlled with access control list used on each device. Members of one group cannot access resources defined for other groups unless explicitly permitted. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-7: Unsuccessful Logon Attempts

The information system: a. Enforces a limit of [Assignment: organization-defined number] consecutive invalid logon attempts by a user during a [Assignment: organization-defined time period]; and b. Automatically [Selection: locks the account/node for an [Assignment: organization-defined time period]; locks the account/node until released by an administrator; delays next logon prompt according to [Assignment: organization-defined delay algorithm]] when the maximum number of unsuccessful attempts is exceeded.
The information system enforces a limit of three consecutive invalid access attempts by a user within any time period. The information system automatically locks the account/node indefinitely or until an administrator unlocks the account when the maximum number of unsuccessful attempts is exceeded. **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system locks out users after three unsuccessful login attempts. The information system automatically locks the account permanently, unless an administrator unlocks the account before then, when the maximum number of unsuccessful attempts (3) is exceeded. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-8: System Use Notification

The information system: a. Displays to users [Assignment: organization-defined system use notification message or banner] before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance and states that: a.1. Users are accessing a U.S. Government information system; a.2. Information system usage may be monitored, recorded, and subject to audit; a.3. Unauthorized use of the information system is prohibited and subject to criminal and civil penalties; and a.4. Use of the information system indicates consent to monitoring and recording; b. Retains the notification message or banner on the screen until users acknowledge the usage conditions and take explicit actions to log on to or further access the information system; and c. For publicly accessible systems: c.1. Displays system use information [Assignment: organization-defined conditions], before granting further access; c.2. Displays references, if any, to monitoring, recording, or auditing that are consistent with privacy accommodations for such systems that generally prohibit those activities; and c.3. Includes a description of the authorized uses of the system.
The information system displays an approved, system use notification message before granting system access informing potential users: (i) that the user is accessing a U.S. Government information system; (ii) that system usage may be monitored, recorded, and subject to audit; (iii) that unauthorized use of the system is prohibited and subject to criminal and civil penalties; and (iv) that use of the system indicates consent to monitoring and recording. The system use notification message provides appropriate privacy and security notices (based on associated privacy and security policies or summaries) and remains on the screen until the user takes explicit actions to log on to the information system. **In-Place Controls:** A warning banner ensures that all persons attempting to gain access to the system know that the system and its information are “Authorized User Only” and that attempts to illegally log on to the system could lead to criminal prosecution. The warning message displayed notifies unauthorized users that they have accessed a U.S. Government computer system and continued, unauthorized use can be punishable by fines or imprisonment. Each device logged into will display a system use notification message before the log in window is displayed. The system use notification banner will remain on the screen until the user takes an explicit action to log on to the device. The following is the notification banner displayed on all Department devices: **WARNING:** This system is for the use of authorized users only. Individuals using this computer system without authority, or in excess of their authority, are subject to having all of their activities on this system monitored and recorded by system personnel. In the event of monitoring individuals improperly using this system, or in the event of system maintenance, the activities of authorized users may also be monitored. Anyone using this system expressly consents to such monitoring and is advised that if such monitoring reveals possible evidence of criminal activity, system personnel may provide the evidence of such monitoring to law enforcement officials. **Control Type:** Hybrid

AC-13: Supervision And Review - Access Control

The Department supervises and reviews the activities of users with respect to the enforcement and usage of information system access controls. **In-Place Controls:** The Department or its designated support staff reviews the activities of users with respect to the enforcement and usage of information system access controls. The designated security officer will review audit records for inappropriate activities in accordance with the Department’s procedures on a weekly basis. Any unusual information system-related activities will be researched and investigated. The security officer will review any changes or additions to access authorizations. User activities are logged and the data reviewed by the system administrator and security officer on a weekly basis: * logon/logoff by User ID * password change * create/delete/open/close file name * program initiation * all SA and database administrator (DBA) actions *NOTE: In accordance with NIST Special Publication 800-53, Recommended Security Controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations, Rev 3, August 2009, updated 01 May 2010; this control was removed entirely and will not show up in the Security Control Compliance Checklist from this point forward.* **Control Type:** Hybrid

AC-14: Permitted Actions Without Identification Or Authentication

The organization: a. Identifies [Assignment: organization-defined user actions] that can be performed on the information system without identification or authentication consistent with organizational missions/business functions; and b. Documents and provides supporting rationale in the security plan for the information system, user actions not requiring identification or authentication.
The Department identifies, documents and limits the specific user actions that can be performed on the information system without identification or authentication. **In-Place Controls:** The Department of Sobriety allows the general public user to read the web pages, do searches on the resource database and to review online forum information without identification and authentication for the public web site. Program and Privilege users cannot access {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system without identification or authentication. **Control Type:** Hybrid

AC-17: Remote Access

The organization: a. Establishes and documents usage restrictions, configuration/connection requirements, and implementation guidance for each type of remote access allowed; and b. Authorizes remote access to the information system prior to allowing such connections.
All methods of remote access (e.g., dial-up, broadband, wireless) to the information system are authorized, monitored, and controlled to protect against unauthorized connections (e.g., limiting dial-up access based upon source of request, using virtual private network technology). **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System permits remote access for privileged functions to support operational needs. The technical staff documents, monitors, and controls all methods of remote access to the information system including remote access for privileged functions. Privileged user access is only permitted through the use of Secure Shell (SSH) or the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) where the user will authenticate to the device through this secure channel. Virtual Private Networking (VPN) is not enabled in any form within the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} accreditation boundary. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-18: Wireless Access

The organization: a. Establishes usage restrictions, configuration/connection requirements, and implementation guidance for wireless access; and b. Authorizes wireless access to the information system prior to allowing such connections.
The Department establishes usage restrictions and implementation guidance for wireless technologies and documents, monitors, and controls wireless access to the information system. Appropriate organizational officials authorize the use of wireless technologies. **In-Place Controls:** N/A – The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System does not use wireless technologies. Scoping Guidance Applied: N/A – The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System does not use wireless technologies. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-19: Access Control For Mobile Devices

The organization: a. Establishes usage restrictions, configuration requirements, connection requirements, and implementation guidance for organization-controlled mobile devices; and b. Authorizes the connection of mobile devices to organizational information systems.
The Department establishes usage restrictions and implementation guidance for organization-controlled mobile devices; authorizes connection of mobile devices meeting organizational usage restrictions and implementation guidance to organizational information systems; monitors for unauthorized connections of mobile devices to organizational information systems; enforces requirements for the connection of mobile devices to organizational information systems; disables information system functionality that provides the capability for automatic execution of code on mobile devices without user direction; issues specially configured mobile devices to individuals traveling to locations that the organization deems to be of significant risk in accordance with organizational policies and procedures; and application the Department’s defined inspection and preventative measures to mobile devices returning from locations that the organization deems to be of significant risk in accordance with the Department’s policies and procedures. **In-Place Controls:** N/A – In accordance with Section 5.9, Portable Electronic Devices (PED) and Access Control for Mobile Devices, of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System Security Policy, the Department does not use portable or mobile devices within or in support of the TACR. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-20: Use Of External Information Systems

The organization establishes terms and conditions, consistent with any trust relationships established with other organizations owning, operating, and/or maintaining external information systems, allowing authorized individuals to: a. Access the information system from external information systems; and b. Process, store, or transmit organization-controlled information using external information systems.
The Department restricts the use of external information systems by authorized individuals conducting official U.S. Government business involving the processing, storage, or transmission of federal information. **In-Place Controls:** The Department of Sobriety restricts the use of personally owned information systems for official U.S. Government business involving the processing, storage, or transmission of federal information. Privileged users are permitted to use personally owned computing devices to migrate data while off-site, as described in Security Control AC-17. However, users must adhere to the following guidelines: - Use SSH to encrypt the exchange of information - Ensure other users of the personally owned information system will be prevented from accessing federal information - Ensure the protection against the vulnerabilities of wireless technologies, if appropriate - Ensure security capabilities of installed software are updated (e.g., operating system and other software security patches, firewall version updates) to protect against malicious code and other potential threats. **Control Type:** System Specific

AC-22: Publicly Accessible Content

The organization: a. Designates individuals authorized to post information onto a publicly accessible information system; b. Trains authorized individuals to ensure that publicly accessible information does not contain nonpublic information; c. Reviews the proposed content of information prior to posting onto the publicly accessible information system to ensure that nonpublic information is not included; and d. Reviews the content on the publicly accessible information system for nonpublic information [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] and removes such information, if discovered.
The Department designates individuals authorized to post information onto an organizational information system that is publicly accessible; trains authorized individuals to ensure that publicly accessible information does not contain nonpublic information; reviews the proposed content of publicly accessible information for nonpublic information prior to posting onto the organizational information systems; reviews the content on the publicly accessible organizational information system for nonpublic information regularly; and removes nonpublic information from the publicly accessible organizational information system, if discovered. **In-Place Controls:** The Department of Sobriety grants certain {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} support staff members the authority to post publicly accessible content. These individuals must complete {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system security training before being granted access to the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} and before they can post publicly accessible content within the TACR. Furthermore, each authorized individual must follow the procedures delineated within the “Using WordPress” Instruction to ensure they are following a verifiable procedure throughout the entire process. This covers the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} Discussion Lists administration areas, Wiki.tacr.dos.gov, {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} Quarterly Reporting and training tools, and WordPress Content Management systems. Public content is only edited via the WordPress Content Management System. All other content is only viewable by {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system users and protected by hardened access controls. **Control Type:** System Specific

CA - Security Assessment and Authorization

CA-1: Security Assessment And Authorization Policy And Procedures

The organization: a. Develops, documents, and disseminates to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]: a.1. A security assessment and authorization policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance; and a.2. Procedures to facilitate the implementation of the security assessment and authorization policy and associated security assessment and authorization controls; and b. Reviews and updates the current: b.1. Security assessment and authorization policy [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; and b.2. Security assessment and authorization procedures [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].
The Department will develop, disseminate, and periodically review/update (or whenever there is a significant change to the regulatory, operational, or technical environment: (i) formal, documented, security assessment and certification and accreditation policies that address purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, and compliance; and (ii) formal, documented procedures to facilitate the implementation of the security assessment and certification and accreditation policies and associated assessment, certification, and accreditation controls. **In-Place Controls:** The Department has published the Department of Sobriety, Office of the Chief Information Officer, Handbook for Information Assurance Security Policy, Information Assurance Program (Handbook -01) and U. S. Department of Sobriety Information Technology Security, Guide Material for Information Technology Security, Certification and Accreditation Procedures (Handbook -05). Both of these publications are revised periodically. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System Security Policy (SSP) provides guidance on all aspects of security for the protection of {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} information technology resources. **Planned Controls:** The Department will periodically review and update the SSP when there is a significant change to the regulatory, operational, or technical environment. **Control Type:** Common

CA-2: Security Assessments

The organization: a. Develops a security assessment plan that describes the scope of the assessment including: a.1. Security controls and control enhancements under assessment; a.2. Assessment procedures to be used to determine security control effectiveness; and a.3. Assessment environment, assessment team, and assessment roles and responsibilities; b. CA-7: Continuous Monitoring

The organization develops a continuous monitoring strategy and implements a continuous monitoring program that includes: a. Establishment of [Assignment: organization-defined metrics] to be monitored; b. Monitoring of the system is done with the OSSEC-HIDS tool, which sends email alerts to the system management team when it detects issues with the systems. The tool uses log-file analysis and dynamic system characteristics to detect potential issues with the system. The IDS code within the McAfee firewall logs alerts via syslog and that log is one of those constantly monitored by the OSSEC-HIDS tool. When incidents are discovered the ContractorCo team will work with the ISSO to report these incidents according to the Federal Agency Incident Categories and within the require reporting timeframe (References: and the *Department of Sobriety Handbook for Information Security Incident Response and Reporting Procedures, Figure* 3.1). **Control Type:** System Specific

CP-10: Information System Recovery And Reconstitution

The organization provides for the recovery and reconstitution of the information system to a known state after a disruption, compromise, or failure.

This original state means that all system parameters (either default or organization-established) are reset, patches are reinstalled, system and security configuration settings are reestablished, system documentation and operating procedures are available, application and system software is reinstalled, information from the most recent backups is available and the system is fully tested. **Control Type:** System Specific

The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system owners/managers manage user identifiers by: (i) uniquely identifying each user; (ii) verifying the identity of each user; (iii) receiving authorization to issue a user identifier from an appropriate official; (iv) ensuring that the user identifier is issued to the intended party; (v) disabling user identifier after a reasonable period of inactivity as documented in its security procedures; and (vi) archiving user identifiers. The Department reviews and updates this policy as necessary. **Control Type:** Common

IA-2: Identification And Authentication (Organizational Users)

The information system uniquely identifies and authenticates organizational users (or processes acting on behalf of organizational users).
The information system uniquely identifies and authenticates users (or processes acting on behalf of users). The Department establishes guidelines for determining if multifactor authentication is required. An e-authentication risk assessment, per OMB M-04-04, must be conducted to determine the identification and authentication requirements for the system. However, should the assurance requirements determined by the e-authentication risk assessment be less than the minimum requirements of the IA-2 BLSR, than IA-2 shall override the results of the e-authentication risk assessment, and the system must meet the minimum requirements of IA-2. **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system uniquely identifies and authenticates all privileged and program users. This is accomplished through the use of unique user identification and a secret user password. All user IDs are maintained in a database by the system administrator and no identical IDs may be issued. The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system does not process sensitive information, thus it does not employ multifactor authentication. Password requirements are listed under security control IA-5. **Control Type:** System Specific

IA-2(1): Multifactor Authentication

The information system implements multifactor authentication for network access to privileged accounts.
*The information system uses multifactor authentication for network access to privileged accounts.* **Planned Controls:** Privileged accounts, in the case of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system, include the users who have administrative access to the VMware and Windows systems and to the Unix systems where {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} is operating. Since no PIV-card type authentication scheme is in-place, and since the cost and complexity of implementing a PIV scheme is considered unnecessary given the size of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system, the contractor has implemented a scheme that leverages the standard username and password authentication, together with IP-based ACLs on access to all management services. GSMX maintainers have Remote Desktop (RDP) access from restricted IPs to REDACTED (via the `REDACTED` security group). **Control Type:** System Specific

The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System and its technical support staff manage user identifiers by: * Uniquely identifying each user (no duplicate identifiers) * Verifying the identity of each user in person or through a trusted third party * Receiving authorization to issue a user identifier from the security officer via the New User Account Request form * Ensuring that the user identifier is issued to the intended party * Disabling user identifier after 30 days of inactivity * Archiving user identifiers so that no identifiers are reused Table 4.3.4-1: Password Character Classes

The organization manages information system authenticators by: a. Verifying, as part of the initial authenticator distribution, the identity of the individual, group, role, or device receiving the authenticator; b. Establishing initial authenticator content for authenticators defined by the organization; c. Ensuring that authenticators have sufficient strength of mechanism for their intended use; d. Establishing and implementing administrative procedures for initial authenticator distribution, for lost/compromised or damaged authenticators, and for revoking authenticators; e. Changing default content of authenticators prior to information system installation; f. Establishing minimum and maximum lifetime restrictions and reuse conditions for authenticators; g. Changing/refreshing authenticators [Assignment: organization-defined time period by authenticator type]; h. Protecting authenticator content from unauthorized disclosure and modification; i. Requiring individuals to take, and having devices implement, specific security safeguards to protect authenticators; and j. Changing authenticators for group/role accounts when membership to those accounts changes.
Information system authenticators (e.g., tokens, PKI certificates, biometrics, passwords, and key cards) are managed by: (i) defining initial authenticator content; (ii) establishing administrative procedures for initial authenticator distribution, for lost/compromised, or damaged authenticators, and for revoking authenticators; and (iii) changing default authenticators upon information system installation. **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System and its technical support staff will manage authenticators (e.g., passwords, tokens, PKI certificates, key cards) by: * Ensuring that passwords contain at a minimum: * 14 alpha numeric characters if the operating system supports 14 (otherwise 8 alpha numeric characters) * At least one number * At least one special character * At least one capitalized letter * At least one lower case letter * Passwords must be changed at least every 90 days, to reduce the possibility of being compromised through guessing, password cracking, and other means that could be employed to learn a user’s password * The password may not be reused in the next 10 changes and passwords can only be changed once every 24 hours * Group passwords must be changed every 90 days or if a member of the group no longer needs access to that group; if group passwords are used, no group passwords are in use on the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} system. * Users are notified five days before password expires * Null passwords are not allowed * Passwords will not be automated through the use of function keys, scripts, or other methods where passwords may be stored on system * Initial one time use authenticator may be distributed via e-mail or given in person * Forgotten, lost, compromised, or damaged authenticators will need to be reissued by the system administrator * Authenticators will be revoked when users no longer need access to the system * All default authenticators will be changed before any new information system is installation * System boot settings are protected by password, which is not the same as Root password **Control Type:** Hybrid

IA-5(1): Password Based Authentication

The information system, for password-based authentication:
The information system, for password-based authentication: Enforces minimum password complexity of English uppercase characters (A through Z), English lowercase characters (a through z), Base-10 digits (0 through 9), Non-alphanumeric (special) characters (e.g., !, $, \#, %, &, etc.). Enforces an exact eight character length password when new passwords are created; Encrypts passwords in storage and in transmission; Enforces password minimum (24 hours) and maximum (90 days) lifetime restrictions; and Prohibits password reuse for 10 generations. **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} is enforcing the following password parameters: 14 alpha numeric characters if the operating system supports 14 (otherwise 8 alpha numeric characters), at least one number, at least one special character, at least one capitalized letters, at least one lower case letters. Passwords must expire in eight weeks, to reduce the possibility of being compromised through guessing, password cracking, and other means that could be employed to learn a user’s password The password may not be reused in the next 10 changes and passwords can only be changed once every 24 hours. Group passwords must be changed every 90 days or if a member of the group no longer needs access to that group. Users are notified five days before password expires. Null passwords are not allowed. Passwords will not be automated through the use of function keys, scripts, or other methods where passwords may be stored on system. Initial one time use authenticator may be distributed via e-mail or given in person. Forgotten, lost, compromised, or damaged authenticators will need to be reissued by the system administrator. Authenticators will be revoked when users no longer need access to the system. All default authenticators will be changed before any new information system is installation. System boot settings are protected by password, which is not the same as the root password **Control Type:** Hybrid

IA-6: Authenticator Feedback

The information system obscures feedback of authentication information during the authentication process to protect the information from possible exploitation/use by unauthorized individuals.
The information system provides feedback to a user during an attempted authentication, and that feedback does not compromise the authentication mechanism (i.e.., displaying asterisks when typing in a password). **In-Place Controls:** The {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system obscures feedback of authentication information during the authentication process by displaying asterisks when a user types in a password. **Control Type:** System Specific

IA-7: Cryptographic Module Authentication

The information system implements mechanisms for authentication to a cryptographic module that meet the requirements of applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for such authentication.
For authentication to a cryptographic module, the information system employs authentication methods that meet the requirements of FIPS 140-2 (as amended). **In-Place Controls:** The Department employs authentication methods consistent with NIST FIPS 140-2 requirements. General public access to Department web pages does not require cryptographic authentication. Privileged users accessing Department systems from outside the server room use the public-key cryptographic functionality of Secure Shell (SSH) to encrypt the exchange of information (including the password) between the remote user and the server. Where Transport Layer Security (TLS, aka SSL) is used, cryptographic modules will be configured in accordance with FIPS 140-2. **Control Type:** System Specific

IA-8: Identification And Authentication (Non-Organizational Users)

The information system uniquely identifies and authenticates non-organizational users (or processes acting on behalf of non-organizational users).
*The information system uniquely identifies and authenticates non-organizational users (or processes acting on behalf of non-organizational users).* **In-Place Controls:** All non-organization users must follow procedures for access privileges as described in AC-2. Any non-organizational user must receive written permission from a Department representative to access the TACR. In addition, only temporary access of a specified duration is allowed for non-organizational users directly accessing the system. Once the time period is over or the task completed, the temporary user accounts are removed immediately. Furthermore, the Access Control section of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} SSP illustrates how access control is implemented at the system level. **Control Type:** System Specific

PM-9: Risk Management Strategy

**In-Place Controls:** The Departments, -7 Guide Material for Information Technology Security Risk Assessment Procedures, illustrates that the organizations has developed a comprehensive strategy to manage risk to organization operations and assets, individuals, other organizations and the Nation associated with the operation and use of the TACR. In practice, the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} is evaluated to ensure: * An independent risk assessment is conducted on the system at least every three years or when a significant change occurs to the system to identify risks based on the adequacy of the security controls in place. * Threat sources, both natural and manmade, are identified and a list of known system vulnerabilities that could be exploited by a threat source is developed and updated. * A mission/ business impact analysis is conducted. * All security controls, currently implemented and planned, are consistent with the system criticality and data sensitivity levels. * The system criticality and data sensitivity levels of the system are determined and documented. * Corrective actions are developed and implemented by management to address system risks identified during independent risk assessments and security reviews. **Control Type:** Common

The levels of risk still need to be designated by the Department for employee and contractor positions but since the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system does not have any sensitive data, a low risk scenario can be assumed. Employee risk levels and background investigations are: Low Risk= NACI, Moderate Risk= LBI, High Risk= BI. Contractor risk levels and background investigations are: Low Risk= NACI, Moderate Risk= NACC, High Risk= BI. In order to ensure every employee is assigned to a position, which has been reviewed for sensitivity by the NCC, the SPD is a required data attribute of an employee’s HR record. Position risks designations are reviewed and revised when NCC or OPM publish changes to sensitivity levels. **Control Type:** Hybrid

RA-3: Risk Assessment

The organization: a. Conducts an assessment of risk, including the likelihood and magnitude of harm, from the unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of the information system and the information it processes, stores, or transmits; b. Documents risk assessment results in [Selection: security plan; risk assessment report; [Assignment: organization-defined document]]; c. Reviews risk assessment results [Assignment: organization-defined frequency]; d. Disseminates risk assessment results to [Assignment: organization-defined personnel or roles]; and e. Updates the risk assessment [Assignment: organization-defined frequency] or whenever there are significant changes to the information system or environment of operation (including the identification of new threats and vulnerabilities), or other conditions that may impact the security state of the system.
Assessments are conducted of the risk and magnitude of harm that could result from the unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of information and information systems that support the operations and assets of the agency. **Planned Controls:** Risk assessments will be conducted to ensure adequate security commensurate with the risk and magnitude of harm that could result from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, disruption, modification, or destruction of information or assets supporting the application. The risk assessment approach includes identification of threats, vulnerabilities, and the effectiveness of the current or planned security controls. A risk assessment has not been performed for this application; however, a risk assessment will be conducted in accordance with NIST SP 800-30 as part of the C&A process. A risk assessment is triggered when significant changes to the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System occur. Some changes to the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} accreditation boundary can impact the overall security posture of the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} Technology project. Some examples of what would constitute a risk assessment are as follows: - Level of criticality and/or sensitivity change for the system/environment impacting reliable baseline countermeasures. - Hardware additions, changes or upgrades requiring a change in the approved security countermeasures. - A device is added to the current accreditation boundary (Example: New server) - Software (operating system or applications) additions, changes or upgrades (e.g., additional functional and capability modules). - Core version changes (Examples: Windows 2000 SP4 to Windows XP, Windows XP to SuSE Linux, Oracle 10g to 11g, Microsoft Access to SQL, etc.) - Security policy (e.g., access control policy) changes. - Threat change creating system vulnerability resulting in a higher risk. - Mission changes requiring a different security mode of operation. - Breaches of security, system integrity or unusual situations that appear to invalidate the accreditation by revealing flaws in security design exposing its vulnerability. - Significant changes in the physical structure of the facility or the system is moved to a different facility. - Significant changes in operating procedures. - A new function is added to the application/system (Example: Application/System XYZ needs to work with FIPS 140-2 802.11b products wirelessly.) - System configuration changes (e.g., a workstation connected outside of the approved accreditation parameters). - Networks: - Inclusion of additional (separately accredited) system(s) affecting the security of that system. - Modification/replacement of a subscribing system affecting the security of that system. - Results of an audit or external analysis. - Addition of system interfaces with other systems. **Control Type:** System Specific

RA-4: Risk Assessment Update

None
The risk assessment of system controls is updated a minimum of every 3 years or whenever there are significant changes to the information system, the facilities where the system resides, or other conditions that may impact the security or accreditation status of the system. A system self-assessment is conducted annually or whenever there are significant changes to the information system, the facilities where the system resides, or other conditions that may impact the security or accreditation status of the system. **Planned Controls:** As described in the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System Risk Assessment and the Department of Sobriety Handbook for Information Assurance Security Policy (Handbook -01), partial risk assessments will be performed annually and a complete assessment will be completed upon re-accreditation of the system. Risks will be reassessed when there is a major change to the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System system or due to other conditions that may have an impact on the {{project.system_profile.system_basics.system_nickname}} System’s security posture. Risk assessment results will be reported to the /IA. NOTE: In accordance with NIST Special Publication 800-53, Recommended Security Controls for Federal Information Systems and Organizations, Rev 3, August 2009, updated 01 May 2010; this control was removed and is now incorporated within RA-3 and will not show up in the Security Control Compliance Checklist from this point forward. **Control Type:** System Specific
